name: Building Blocks
description: 30 more essential words to strengthen your vocabulary

words.definition: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
examples: The room had a modern aesthetic with clean lines.
She made aesthetic choices in decorating her home.

words.definition: Very old or old-fashioned; belonging to an earlier period.
examples: The archaic computer system needed updating.
Shakespeare used many archaic words.

words.definition: Concise and exact use of words; shortness of time.
examples: The brevity of his speech was appreciated.
Brevity is the soul of wit, according to Shakespeare.

words.definition: Characterized by unity; forming a united whole.
examples: The team worked together in a cohesive manner.
A cohesive argument is more persuasive.

words.definition: Logical and consistent; easy to understand.
examples: Her coherent explanation clarified the complex issue.
The witness gave a coherent account of events.

words.definition: Evoking interest or attention in a powerful way.
examples: The documentary presented a compelling argument.
She found his story compelling and believable.

words.definition: Giving a lot of information clearly in few words.
examples: Please provide a concise summary of the report.
His concise writing style saved time.

words.definition: Able to be believed; convincing.
examples: The witness provided credible testimony.
Her credentials made her a credible expert.

words.definition: Publicly declare to be wrong or evil.
examples: The senator denounced the corrupt practices.
Many groups denounced the violence.

words.definition: Discourage someone from doing something.
examples: The high cost deterred many buyers.
Security cameras deter theft.

words.definition: A great difference or inequality.
examples: There's a disparity between rich and poor.
The disparity in test scores was concerning.

words.definition: Hesitating or doubting; not to be relied upon.
examples: I'm dubious about his ability to finish on time.
The evidence was of dubious authenticity.

words.definition: Difficult to find, catch, or achieve.
examples: Success remained elusive despite their efforts.
The elusive criminal evaded capture for years.

words.definition: Intensify, increase, or further improve the quality of.
examples: The spices enhance the flavor of the dish.
Exercise can enhance your mood.

words.definition: Possible to do easily or conveniently.
examples: The project is feasible within our budget.
Is it feasible to finish by Friday?

words.definition: Not having any serious purpose or value.
examples: The lawsuit was dismissed as frivolous.
She spent money on frivolous purchases.

words.definition: Based on a suggested idea rather than reality.
examples: Let me pose a hypothetical question.
The discussion remained purely hypothetical.

words.definition: Treating all rivals or disputants equally; fair.
examples: The judge must remain impartial.
An impartial mediator helped resolve the dispute.

words.definition: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.
examples: She was indifferent to his complaints.
The crowd remained indifferent to the speaker.

words.definition: Featuring new methods; advanced and original.
examples: The company's innovative approach changed the industry.
She proposed an innovative solution.

words.definition: Responsible by law; likely to do or experience something.
examples: The company is liable for damages.
You're liable to catch cold in this weather.

words.definition: Failing to take proper care in doing something.
examples: The negligent driver caused an accident.
Negligent maintenance led to the breakdown.

words.definition: No longer produced or used; out of date.
examples: The obsolete technology was replaced.
Floppy disks are now obsolete.

words.definition: Seeming reasonable or probable.
examples: Her explanation sounded plausible.
The theory is plausible but unproven.

words.definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
examples: It would be prudent to save money.
The prudent investor diversified her portfolio.

words.definition: Not needed because something else serves the same purpose.
examples: The safety features include redundant systems.
His explanation was redundant and repetitive.

words.definition: Not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations.
examples: I'm skeptical about his claims.
The skeptical scientist demanded more evidence.

words.definition: So delicate or precise as to be difficult to perceive.
examples: There was a subtle difference in the colors.
Her subtle hint went unnoticed.

words.definition: Perceptible by touch; clear and definite.
examples: The project showed tangible results.
We need tangible evidence, not speculation.

words.definition: Of little value or importance.
examples: Don't worry about trivial matters.
The error was trivial and easily fixed.
